backend.file

Class BlockBuffer

  • java.lang.Object
    • backend.file.BlockBuffer

  • public class BlockBuffer
extends java.lang.Object
    Read and write blocks from a file. This implementation limits the file size to Integer.MAX_VALUE * 1024 bytes (about 2 TB, depending on the JVM) TODO: Make thread safe
    Author:
    iiMaXii

        • Constructor Detail

          • BlockBuffer

            public BlockBuffer(java.lang.String filename,
                   BlockBuffer.Mode mode)
            throws java.nio.file.NoSuchFileException,
                   java.io.IOException
            Open a file
            Option Description
            READ Open the file for reading only. If the file does not exist NoSuchFileException will be thrown.
            READ_WRITE Open the file for reading and writing. If the file does not exist NoSuchFileException will be thrown.
            CREATE_READ_WRITE Open the file for reading and writing. Will attempt to create the file, failing if the file already exists.
            Parameters:
            filename - The path to the file
            blockCount - The number of blocks in the file
            mode -
            Throws:
            java.io.IOException
            java.nio.file.NoSuchFileException

            public int getBlock(byte[] buffer,
                    int blockNumber)
             throws java.io.IOException
            Read a block from the file
            Parameters:
            buffer -
            blockNumber -
            Returns:
            The number of bytes read, possibly zero, or -1 if the given position is greater than or equal to the file's current size
            Throws:
            java.io.IOException

          • getMode

            public BlockBuffer.Mode getMode()
            Get the mode that was used to create the file
            Returns:
            The file mode

          • getBlockCount

            public int getBlockCount()
                  throws java.io.IOException
            Get the block count of the file. Calling this method for a file that is open for writing might give unexpected results, since BlockBuffer is unaware of the file size when creating the file
            Returns:
            The file block count
            Throws:
            java.io.IOException
